results.title: Freeze-in
results.creator_credit: F Whitman Trecartin, Albert Kish and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A film essay without commentary about the port of Montreal as winter closes in - the last-minute scurry as ships that can make it dash for open water, while those that cannot prepare for a long hold-over. On the docks all activity seems suspended as the numbing cold closes its grip. But there is activity on the iced-in ships and in the freight sheds, making ready for the time when the icebreakers open a river channel and traffic returns. Film without words.
results.creator_credit_for_label: F Whitman Trecartin, Albert Kish and ONF | NFB

results.title: Freestyle
results.creator_credit: David Lowe, Matt Morgan and AFTRS
results.brief_description: The police investigating the murder of a young male swimmer interview a woman who regularly swims in the pool where he was murdered. Did she really not see anything?

results.title: Freefall
results.creator_credit: Arts Council of Great Britain and David Stacey
results.brief_description: The choreographer and dancer, Gaby Agis, has a unique style, taking dance out of the confines of the theatre and into new spaces and contexts. For this film she has taken the dance to the city, essentially London. Gaby and her Company move through narrow streets and alleys, over rooftops, constant building sites and sudden, quiet green spaces, touching in a synthesis of choreography and place only possible through film.

results.title: Freedom or death
results.creator_credit: Curtis Levy, Christine Levy, AFFC and Olsen Levy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Riding the tiger”.
Indonesia has one of the most militarised and organised populations in the world. From a very young age Indonesian civilians undertake training in various forms of youth groups, neighbourhood councils etc. which are all linked to the military government. In this episode the strength and power of the military is traced back to the feudal roots of Indonesia; to the resistance movements against the Dutch colonisers; the role of the Japanese army in training the Indonesians; and the underground resistance of the late 1940s which overthrew first the British occupiers of the country, then the returning Dutch administration.

results.title: Free to Move
results.creator_credit: Brian Lewis, Derek Monk, Ted Channell, Schools Council and Southern Films
results.brief_description: Attempts to show that physical education is concerned with the education of the whole child, not only his physical well being. Shows need for a broad based and varied programme of activities; and how related work in other areas of the curriculum may spring from or lead to work in movement. Presents a composite picture of the balanced programme offered in a good primary school.

results.title: Free to move
results.brief_description: This video is about friction: the resistance generated when one solid surface slides in contact with another. It is also about how we reduce the forces of friction by lubrication and how lubrication controls wear, to lengthen the life of the moving parts of machinery.

results.title: Free to be, you and me
results.creator_credit: Carole Hart, Marlo Thomas, Bill Davis and Murakami-Wolf Productions
results.brief_description: A special program designed for a more structural approach to exploration of personal development concepts. Includes an all star cast from stage and screen, presenting in live action, animation and puppetry two thematically designed units: Friendship and co-operation; Expectations and independence. Features Alan Alda, Harry Belafonte, Mel Brooks, Rita Coolidge, Billy the Wolfe, Roberta Flack, Michael Jackson, Kris Kristofferson, Bobby Morse, The New Seekers, Tom Smothers, Cecily Tyson, The Voices ofo East Harlem and Dionne Warwick.

results.title: Free cinema
results.creator_credit: John Fletcher, Karel Reisz, Lindsay Anderson, Leon Clore, Graphic Films and Graphic Production
results.brief_description: ‘Free Cinema’ was not a movement so much as a group of young filmmakers (including Lindsay Anderson, Tony Richardson and Karel Reisz), reacting against the class bound British cinema by working outside the dictates of the industry, although not entirely without its support. The filmmakers use of lighter and more flexible camera equipment and faster film stock, combined with their portrayal of contemporary life, injected the British documentary tradition with a new life. While inevitably portraying working class life from a middle class perspective which was not always free from left-wing sentimentality, ‘Free Cinema’ filmmakers did turn their cameras on previously ignored (on film), areas of British life. ‘Every Day Except Christmas’ (Dir; Lindsay Anderson, 40 mins. 1957) is a lyrical, implicitly idealistic, portrayal of working class community at the Covent Garden Market. ‘We Are the Lambeth Boys’ (Dir; Karel Reisz, 50 mins. 1959) tries to get close to working class youth culture. ‘The Saturday Men’ (Dir; John Fletcher, 29 mins. 1959) is the portrait of a football club.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Fletcher, Karel Reisz, Lindsay Anderson, Leon Clore, Graphic Films and Graphic Production

results.title: Fred Astaire: change partners and dance
results.creator_credit: David Heeley, Educational Broadcasting Corporation and Public Television Stations
results.brief_description: The famous dancing partnership of Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire ended in 1939 but this did not mean the end for Fred Astaire. In this documentary you will see Astaire “change partners and dance” like never before. Using excerpts from many of his films including “You’ll never get rich” (1941), “Daddy Long Legs” (1955), “Funny face” (1957), we meet some of those partners, often highly regarded in their own right, including Rita Hayworth, Betty Hutton, Leslie Caron, Audrey Hepburn and Barrie Chase. The passing decades reflect Astaire’s change in his dancing movements from swing and tap of the 1940s to cool jazz of the 1950s and 1960s. Also includes interviews with Leslie Caron, Barrie Chase, Bob Fosse, Rodolf Nureyev, Hermes Pan, Jerome Robbins, Roland Petit and others with some rare footage from Astaire’s first television appearance in 1958 on “Toast of the town”. Last but not least is an excerpt from his final television special in 1968 featuring the classic “Puttin’ on the ritz”. Contains b&w footage. Narrated by Joanne Woodward.
